(1) The obligation of sponsors and fidepromissors did not descend to their heirs, Gaius iii. 120. (2) By a lex Publilia oi uncertain date a sponsor who paid the debt could, unless repaid by the principal within six months, recover twice the amount by actio depensi, Gaius iv. 22. (3) The lex Furia de sponsu, circ. lac. 95 (which, however, extended only to Italy), limited the liability of sponsors and fidepromissors to two years from the date of their contract, and also (4) where there were two or more os them, divided the liability among all who were living at the time when the guarantee could be enlorced, so that each could be sued for only an aliquot share, Gaius iii. 121. (5) The lex Apuleiana 102 (extending also to the provinces), conferred a less but similar boon ou sponsors and iidepromissors even outside ltaly, by giving to any one ol them who paid the whole debt an actio pro socio against the rest, by which he could recover what he had paid in excess of his fair share, Gaius iii. 122. (6) Α statute whose name is illegible in the MS. os Gaius, iii. ¹23 (Cicereia, Rudorffl, provided that a creditor, on taking sponsore or fidepromissors, should first state openly what the debt to be guaranteed was, and also the number oi sureties he was going to take ; il this were not done, they could by taking action within thirty days procuro their release. Gaius says that this enactment had by usage been extended to fideiussors also, but it was obsolete under Justinian.

Fideiussio, like sponsio and fidepromissio, is a form ot' what is called cumulative intercession, which may be defined as a contract between a creditor and a third person by which the latter takes upon himself the debtor's obligation without the debtor being himself released. The form in which fideiussio was contracted was ‘idem fide tua esse iubes? fideiubeo' (Gaius iii. 116), so that the obligation of the principal and surety was correal: the Greek equivalents are given in ξ 7 ini.
